title.narrative: Provision of life saving assistance to children under five years of age suffering from Sever acute malnutrition (SAM) in Borno state, north east Nigeria

description.narrative: Plan International Nigeria will implement a 12-month project focusing on improving access to quality curative nutrition services and strengthening capacity for the management of severe acute malnutrition in Stabilization Centers (SC). This will be done through screening amp referral of treated Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) cases from SC to OTP, treatment of Complicated SAM cases in SC and promoting Optimal IYCF-E (Infant and Young Child Feeding in Emergencies) in the SCs for Kaga, Konduga, Mafa, Hawul, and Chibok Local Government Areas (LGAs) in Borno state. The project proposes to provide treatment of complicated SAM cases for a total of 1,945 children under five-years of age in 5 Stabilization Centers (SC) and promoting IYCF-E for SAM care takers/mothers and PLWs in the SCs. The proposed activities will strengthen the management of acute malnutrition through CMAM approach by strengthening existing SC sites for IDP/host community and providing Optimal IYCF Promotion, providing technical and logistical support, as well as strengthening the supportive supervision in the LGAs. The project will focus on supporting the most vulnerable population groups, specifically children under five years of age and caretakers of SAM children and other vulnerable groups. Plan International will integrate management of complicated SAM (SAM with medical complication and /or failed appetite test) cases into existing health services in each general hospitals using SPHCDA and hospital staff in all targeted LGAs. At project start-up, Plan International Nigeria will prioritize identifying Complicated SAM cases to facilitate access to life-saving services for children under five years of age with complicated SAM cases and to enable management of these cases in collaboration with State Primary Health Care and Development Agency (SPHCDA) and hospital board staff. We will strengthen the capacity of the government service providers and mothers/care takers to prevent malnutrition and respond to the treatment of complicated SAM cases and we will work closely with government s and partners working in each LGAs. The project will strengthen accountability to beneficiaries through the establishment and strengthening of a community and facility -based complaints and feedback mechanism that will allow women, girls, men, and boys to safely report concerns of the emergency nutrition response in their respective Hospital.
